history: Crosby Gaige's Cocktail Guide, 1945. Arsenic and Old Lace is a play by American playwright Joseph Kesselring, written in 1939. It has become best known through the film adaptation starring Cary Grant and directed by Frank Capra. The play was directed by Bretaigne Windust, and opened on 10 January 1941. On 25 September 1943, the play moved to the Hudson Theater. It closed there on 17 June 1944 having played 1,444 performances.

name: Daiquiri
summary: rum, lime, simple
recipe: Add all ingredients to shaker, fill completely with ice and shake vigorously. Strain into glass.
history: The holy trinity of Caribbean cocktails: rum, lime & sugar. Simple, cold, and exceedingly delicious. This is a foundation for so many drinks. Play around with different funky rums, add some bitters, drop in some fresh seasonal fruit, blend it with ice and serve it with a spoon. Or keep it simple, shake the hell out of it and strain into a chilled coupe. Named after the mining town in Cuba and championed by an American ex-pat engineer by the name of Jennings Cox in the early 1900’s.

history: Daisy's, similar to Sour's and Crusta's, again contain spirit, fresh citrus and a fancy liqueur as the sweetener. Often this was Curucao, Marschino or Triple Sec (Cointreau). They were traditionally topped off with a light splash of club soda. First appeared in a recipe book in Jerry Thomas' "Bartender's Guide", 1862.

name: Dark 'n Stormy
summary: goslings, lime, sweetened ginger juice, club soda
recipe: Add all ingredients to shaker (except club soda) and shake without ice. Pour into iced glass, top with club soda.
history: The national drink of Bermuda. This classic highball has it's origins in a ginger beer factory run by the Royal Naval Officer's Club. Some savvy sailor's found that this ginger beer mixed well with a splash of the local rum (Gosling's Black Seal). The appearance of the drink is said to have inspired it's name as it was "the color of a cloud only a fool or dead man would sail under". The forever house drink of 134 Eldridge.

name: French '75

recipe: Add all ingredients (except champagne) to shaker, fill completely with ice and shake vigorously, strain into glass and top with champagne.
history: Harry MacElhone, Harry's New York Bar, Paris, 1915. The combination was said to have such a kick that it felt like being shelled with the powerful French 75mm howitzer artillery piece. The French 75 was popularized in America at the Stork Club. The drink's recipe was first recorded in The Savoy Cocktail Book in 1930. A later cocktail book The Fine Art of Mixing Drinks by David Embury claims that the French 75 is a Cognac based drink.

garnish: Garnish with orange slice and nutmeg.

Leave in mug and add other ingredients, lightly muddle to break up the sugar cube. Fill 2/3's full of crushed ice and swizzle. Top up with crushed ice and garnish with mint sprigs (and drizzle of Jamaican rum).

name: Gibson

recipe: Add all ingredients to chilled Boston glass, add cracked ice and stir for approximately 25-30 seconds, strain into chilled glass.
history: A Martini garnished with pickled onions. Called the Gibson, a story exists that General Gibson would have onions as his garnish as opposed to the more traditional olive so that he would be able to distinguish his drink from others at a bar/party. Sounds like a wise man, he would also instruct his barkeep to serve him only water in the glass, no gin or vermouth... Cocktails: How to Mix Them, Robert Vermeire, 1922

name: Gimblet

history: Although Rose's Sweetened Lime Juice was the traditional ingredient in the Gimlet, this was partly due to the short shelf life of limes and their juice, especially in the warm colonies of the British Empire, where this drink was a favorite among the ex-pats. Try muddling a seasonal fruit in here for an extra applause.

Although Don created much of the tiki culture that we know today, it’s apparent that Vic can rightfully claim the origin of this drink as his own.

Leave in mug and add other ingredients, lightly muddle to break up the sugar cube. Fill 2/3's full of crushed ice and swizzle. Top up with crushed ice and garnish with mint sprigs (and drizzle of Jamaican rum).
history: This Major preferred gin in his julep. Surprisingly delicious.

name: Manhattan
summary: rye, sweet vermouth, angostura
recipe: Add all ingredients to chilled Boston glass, add cracked ice and stir for approximately 25-30 seconds, strain into chilled glass.
history: First appearing in print in 1882, the Manhattan went by many names: Turf Club Cocktail and Jockey Club just to name a few. It was a combination of the recently available rich, dark Italian Vermouth bartender's had gotten their hands on, American Whiskey and bitters. It first appeared in print in a recipe book in Harry Johnson's Bartender's Manual in 1882 where he also lists the Brooklyn Cocktail.

name: Manhattan (perfect)

history: A dryer version of the Manhattan with both dry and sweet vermouth's being used and a lemon twist garnish. See Manhattan for history.

name: Maravilla

name: Margarita

recipe: Add all ingredients to shaker, fill completely with ice and shake vigorously. Strain into glass.
history: Many reports exist about the origins of Mexico's national cocktail. One suggests it was named for a bride at the Garci Crispo Hotel in Puebla, Mexico in 1936. Another report claims that Dona Bertha created this at Bertha's Bar in Taxco, Mexico in 1930. Regardless of which one we believe, there is no disputing that this drink is one of the world's more popular cocktails.

name: Martinez

name: Martini (dry)

recipe: Add all ingredients to chilled Boston glass, add cracked ice and stir for approximately 25-30 seconds, strain into chilled glass.
garnish: Garnish with either a lemon twist or an olive.
history: French or Dry Vermouth arrived in the United States in the 1870's, close to a decade after it's sweeter, darker Italian counterpart. It was only natural that bartenders and enthusiasts alike would start using this product as a substitute for sweet or Italian Vermouth in their cocktails. This cocktail is the dry vermouth version of it's predecessor the Martinez, or, to put it more simply, a gin Manhattan.

recipe: With clean hands (of course), squeeze around 14-16 mint leaves in your hand to release fragrance and coat the entire rim and inside of julep mug with bruised bouquet. Leave in mug and add other ingredients, lightly muddle to break up the sugar cube. Fill 2/3's full of crushed ice and swizzle. Top up with crushed ice and garnish with mint sprigs (and drizzle of Jamaican rum).
history: The drink of the south. The french word julep is derived from the Arab word julab which was a drink made with rose petals. Mint replaced the rose and mixed with American whiskey or rum, the Mint Julep as it is now called became very popular in both Europe and North America. Mint Julep's became the Kentucky Derby's official drink in 1938.

history: From Ted “Dr Cocktail” Haigh: The Mother-In-Law was truly obscure, coming to him from Brooks Baldwin by way of Chuck Taggart. As told to Haigh by Brooks, from Vintage Spirits and Forgotten Cocktails: My grandmother (born in New Orleans in 1895) inherited this recipe from her mother-in-law shortly before the beginning of the First World War. As specified in the original recipe, my mother concocted this libation by the quart and stored it in an antique lead crystal decanter. Informed that science had linked lead crystal to lead poisoning, my grandmother said: “a pretty bottle, so hush”

history: Man's gift, from the Gods. The Negroni was created in Florence, Italy at Bar Casoni, where a Count by the name of Negroni asked for his Americano Cocktail to be spiked with gin. Soon people were asking for their Americano's "The Negroni way". It first appeared in "Cocktails de Paris" as a Camparinete in 1929 and then published under it's current name in the 1939 version of the "Floridita Bar Book". "Take my dignity, just don't take my Negroni..." -Sam Ross to his cruel brother Toby

Empty whiskey glass of crushed ice and absinthe, strain Sazerac mixture into chilled, absinthe-lined whiskey glass.
history: The original all brandy Sazerac from New Orleans. See Sazerac for history.

history: A stimulating liquor composed of spirits of any kind, sugar, water and bitters. This sentence, printed in 1806, is the first know report of the word "cocktail". The Old Fashioned is essentially this, bourbon being the preferred spirit. There are also reports claiming that the Old Fashioned was a product of the Pendennis Club, Kentucky, created in the early 1880's. The oldest recipe for this drink appears in George Kappeler's Modern American Drinks, published in 1895.

history: The classic English summertime cooler. Also the official drink of Wimbledon. This drink was first being made in 1823 when James Pimm opened Pimm's Oyster Bar in London. The drink soon became so popular, he started bottling it to sell to other bars, Pimm's No. 1 was created.

This drink was first being made in 1823 when James Pimm opened Pimm's Oyster Bar in London. The drink soon became so popular, he started bottling it to sell to other bars, Pimm's No. 1 was created.

Originally done with a whole lot more pineapple juice than what we’ve listed, this drink was popularized by the invention of canned coconut cream (Coco Lopez), previously a very time consuming product to make.

We sweeten our version slightly, although this is untraditional, it does help to balance out the acidity of the lime. This formula works very well with any base spirit, although gin is the go-to. Any fresh fruit can be muddled and shaken in for an extra applause. Try black cherries, peaches or strawberries.

garnish: Garnish with a parasol, cinnamon, and a cherry.

name: Sazerac
summary: rye, white sugar cube, peychauds, absinthe
recipe: Fill whiskey glass with crushed ice and 1/4oz absinthe. Allow to chill while you prepare the Sazerac. For Sazerac, add sugar cube to chilled Boston glass, douse in Peychauds Bitters, add a barspoon of club soda and muddle. Add spirits, fill with cracked ice and stir roughly 25 times. Empty whiskey glass of crushed ice and absinthe, strain Sazerac mixture into chilled, absinthe-lined whiskey glass.
history: A New Orleans icon, originally made by Apothecarian Antoine Amedee Peychauds at his shop in 1830, it was an interesting mixture of brandy and his own bitters, designed to soothe one's ailments. With the demand for his drink high, the drink started popping up in bars all over New Orleans, in particular the Merchants Exchange Coffee House. The owner, also a liquor importer, started making the drink with a type of Cognac called Sazerac-du-Forge et Fils. The bar changed hands and the new owner renamed it the Sazerac Coffee House. Rye whiskey replaced the Cognac somewhere around the 1870's when Cognac became very difficult to obtain.

name: Sidecar
summary: cognac, lemon, cointreau, Simple
recipe: Add all ingredients to shaker, fill completely with ice and shake vigorously. Strain into glass.
history: As per most classic cocktails, the exact origin of this drink remain slightly unclear. The first recipes for the Sidecar appear in 1922, in Harry MacElhone's "Harry's ABC of Mixing Cocktails" and Robert Vermeire's "Cocktails and How to Mix Them". In early editions of MacElhone's book, he cites the inventor as Pat MacGarry, "the Popular bar-tender at Buck's Club, London," but in later editions he cites himself. Vermiere states, "This cocktail is very popular in France. It was first introduced in London by MacGarry, the celebrated bar-tender of Buck's Club."

Pineapple juice, when fresh, is often preferred over the orange, this however did occur many years after the original was made.

Degroff muddled lemon wedges in his rye whiskey version. This formula works wonderfully with any spirit, bitters can also be added to complement the mint.

name: Whiskey Freezer
summary: Bourbon, Lime, Simple, Fresh Mint, Club Soda
recipe: Add all ingredients (except club soda) to shaker, fill completely with ice and shake vigorously, strain into glass and top with club soda.
garnish: Garnish with a lime wedge and fresh mint.
history: A bourbon Southside rickey. Published in “A Spot at the Bar” Michael Madrusan and Zara Young, 2016

name: White Lady
summary: gin, lemon, cointreau, egg white
recipe: Add all ingredients to shaker and shake without ice (to emulsify egg), add ice and shake vigorously, strain into glass.
history: A Gin Sidecar that was incredibly popular in Europe in the 20th Century. Harry MacElhone of Ciro's and later Harry's New York Bar in Paris created the first drink of this name in 1919 , he changed the recipe roughly a decade later where it was also chronicled in Harry Craddock's Savoy Cocktail Book (1930). There has forever been a dispute as to who first mixed this tasty recipe as we make today, Craddock or MacElhone?

name: White Negroni
summary: Gin, Suze , Blanc Vermouth
recipe: Add all ingredients glass, add ice and stir 5 or 6 times.
history: Credited to the legendary Wayne Collins of London. Dry, herbaceous, delicious!

name: White Russian
summary: vodka, Lolita, hand whipped cream float
recipe: Add all ingredients to chilled Boston glass, add cracked ice and stir for approximately 25-30 seconds, strain into chilled glass.
history: The dude abides man.

name: White collar
summary: Rye, Amaro CioCiaro, Blanc vermouth, Maraschino Liqueur , Orange Bitters
recipe: Add all ingredients to chilled Boston glass, add cracked ice and stir for approximately 25-30 seconds, strain into chilled glass.
history: Aromatic, amaro-laced Manhattan riff. Zachary gelnaw-rubin, Dutch Kills, 2014

name: White horse
summary: Scotch, Pineapple, Sweetened Ginger juice , Lime, Angostura Bitters, Club Soda
recipe: Add all ingredients to shaker (except club soda) and shake with ice. Pour into iced glass, top with club soda.
garnish: Garnish with an orange slice and candied ginger.
history: Jacques Straub, “drinks”, 1914

name: Whole Lotta Rosa
summary: Cocchi Rosa, Gin, Lemon, Simple, Orange slices, Egg white
recipe: Add all ingredients to shaker and shake without ice (to emulsify egg), add ice and shake vigorously, strain into glass. Top with club soda.
history: Light, floral fizz utilizing Cocchi Rosa as the hero and named for the cracking AC/DC song. Michael Madrusan, The Everleigh, Melbourne, 2013

name: Wild Eyed Rose
summary: irish whiskey, lime, grenadine
recipe: Add all ingredients to shaker, fill completely with ice and shake vigorously. Strain into glass.
history: Victor Bergeron, Bartender's Guide by Trader Vic, 1947

name: Williams Fizz
summary: pear  brandy, applejack, lemon, simple, egg white, club soda
recipe: Add all ingredients to shaker (except club soda) and shake without ice (to emulsify egg), add ice and shake vigorously, strain into glass and top with club soda.
history: Toby Maloney, Milk & Honey, NYC, 2003

name: Winner’s circle
summary: Bourbon, Creme de cacao, Lemon, Angostura Bitters
recipe: Add all ingredients to shaker (except bitters), fill completely with ice and shake vigorously. Strain into glass. Float Angosutra Bitters.
history: Stiff and citrusy whilst still being on the drier side. Matty Clark, Dutch Kills, 2017

name: Winter Buck
summary: Jamaican Rum, Allspice Dram (floated), Lime, Ginger Syrup, Club Soda
recipe: Add all ingredients to shaker (except club Soda and Allspice Dram) and shake without ice. Pour into iced glass, top with club soda and float Allspice Dram.
history: A cognac buck sweetened up with some allspice.

name: Woolworth
summary: Highland Scotch, Amontillado Sherry, Islay Scotch, Benedictine, Orange bitters
recipe: Add ingredients to glass, add ice and stir 5 or 6 times.
history: Smoky and nutty Scotch sipper. John Deragon, Please Don’t Tell, NYC, 2007

name: XYZ
summary: aged rum, lemon, cointreau
recipe: Add all ingredients to shaker, fill completely with ice and shake vigorously. Strain into glass.
history: Savoy, Harry Craddock, first published 1930

name: Xeres
summary: Fino Sherry , Orange Bitters, Peach Bitters
recipe: Add all ingredients to chilled Boston glass, add cracked ice and stir for approximately 25-30 seconds, strain into chilled glass.
history: Simply fino Sherry and bitters stirred in the style of a Martini. Surprisingly tasty. Published in “A Spot at the Bar” Michael Madrusan and Zara Young, 2016

name: Yale Cocktail
summary: gin, dry vermouth, maraschino, orange bitters
recipe: Add all ingredients to chilled Boston glass, add cracked ice and stir for approximately 25-30 seconds, strain into chilled glass.
history: This Martini variant comes from the Ivy League School of the same name.

name: Yankee Julep
summary: rye, simple, mint, white sugar cube
recipe: Add all ingredients to glass, muddle sugar cube, add ice and stir.
garnish: Garnish with a bouquet of fresh mint.
history: During Civil War times, the Yankees would drink rye whiskey whilst the Rebels would douse their victories and sorrows with bourbon. The Yankee Julep uses all rye.

name: Young American
summary: Sweet Vermouth, Campari, Aperol, Absinthe , Club Soda
recipe: Add all ingredients glass, add ice and stir 5 or 6 times.
history: Created for a James Beard event in Los Angeles in 2009. Michael Madrusan, Milk & Honey, NYC, 2009

name: Zebra
summary: Tequila, Campari, Lime, Simple, Orange Bitters, Club Soda
recipe: Add all ingredients to shaker (except club soda) and shake without ice. Pour into iced glass, top with club soda.
history: A Tequila rickey with Campari - bitter and vegetal. So named because it’s roughly the same color as the inside of a zebra. Felix Allsop, The Everleigh, Melbourne, 2015

name: Zephyr
summary: gin, cocchi americano or lillet blanc, green chartreuse
recipe: Add all ingredients to chilled Boston glass, add cracked ice and stir for approximately 25-30 seconds, strain into chilled glass.
history: Benjamin Schwartz, Little Branch, NYC, 2010

name: Zombie

ingredients.name: 0.5 oz curaçao, 0.5 oz grenadine, 2 Dashes Angosutra Bitters

summary: White rum, Aged rum, Lemon/lime (combined), Orange juice, Passionfruit Syrup , 0.5 oz curaçao, 0.5 oz grenadine, 2 Dashes Angosutra Bitters
recipe: Add all ingredients to shaker. Dry shake and pour into mug/glass two third’s full of crushed ice. Add straw and top with more crushed ice.
garnish: Garnish with a parasol, mint sprig, and nutmeg.
history: It first appeared in late 1934, invented by Donn Beach at his Hollywood Don the Beachcomber restaurant. Adapted to a single serve.

name: Zone Amarillo
summary: Mezcal, Reposado tequila, Punt e mes, Yellow chartreuse , Angostura & Peychauds Bitters
recipe: Add all ingredients glass, add ice and stir 5 or 6 times.
garnish: Garnish with an orange twist and a cherry.
history: If a Greenpoint were made with the agaves, it would taste like this. Mike dolfini, attaboy, Nashville, 2019
